history.content:
CS170 is an amazing class, currently taking it right now. But note, it has a CS70 prerequisite; though I'm not sure if its a hard pre-req. Nonetheless, I would argue that the style and rigor of CS70 certainly helps for CS170, even though there is no direct overlap in material. CS61C is also a really cool class if you're interested in the hardware/software interface, and this can lead to super-popular (so perhaps useful?) courses such as CS161 (Security) and CS162 (OS). With just 61A and 61B, and assuming Math54, you can take CS168 (Internet), which I have heard can be pretty interesting at times.

Overall, since you're pressed to a limited number of courses, I would suggest taking a look at the course topics of CS classes and see what you find interesting and are eligible to take. Also doesn't hurt to checkout previous semesters webcasts to get an idea of what the class is about and how its structured.

children.subject:
You need three upper-divs for the EECS minor; what are your other two?

Also: what sorts of "practicality" in terms of subject area are you looking into?
I'm planning on taking EE classes for the other two. By practical, I mean I'd like to be able to independently work on CS projects (e.g. Software/app development)

Thanks for the great advice! I've been spending a lot of time reading through the course catalog, but I've been having trouble wrapping my head around how effective each class is at teaching the subject (some of them seem too specific to be worthwhile if I only have time for two classes).

One idea I had was to take CS61C and 169 (Software Engineering). Does this sound like a good way to wrap up my CS coursework? CS 169 lists CS70 and 61C as prerequisites; do you think I'll be able to get by in the class without having taken those courses?
I'm currently a 4th year BioE major, doubling in EECS. Feel free to hit me up if you have questions

history.content:
Hello,

I'm a BioE major minoring in EECS, and was hoping to get some advice on what classes I should plan to take in the coming semesters. I've taken CS61A and B, but haven't taken 70 and only have time to take two more CS classes. What are some worthwhile, practical classes to take? Since I really don't have time to dive into the bulk of CS, what kinds of classes would you say were the most effective in developing your skills as a computer scientist?

Thanks!
history.subject: BioE EECS Minor Advice?
